articles.headline: Trump Unleashes on Kavanaugh Accuser as Key Republican Wavers
articles.snippet: The Republican, Senator Lisa Murkowski, said she was troubled by Christine Blasey Ford’s story. Senate Republicans hired a sex-crimes prosecutor from Arizona, Rachel Mitchell, to question Dr. Blasey.
articles.abstract: The Republican, Senator Lisa Murkowski, said she was troubled by Christine Blasey Ford’s story. Senate Republicans hired a sex-crimes prosecutor from Arizona, Rachel Mitchell, to question Dr. Blasey.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump assailed the latest woman to accuse Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh of sexual misconduct, saying on Tuesday that she “has nothing” because she was “messed up” at the time, even as a key Republican senator urged colleagues to take the accusations seriously.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: One Reason for Slow Wage Growth? More Benefits
articles.snippet: The rise of nonwage compensation like paid time off is helping persuade the Fed to push up interest rates.
articles.abstract: The rise of nonwage compensation like paid time off is helping persuade the Fed to push up interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the most perplexing questions about the nation’s economic recovery is why a tight labor market has not translated into faster wage growth. Part of the answer appears to be that American workers are receiving a growing share of compensation in the form of benefits rather than wages.

articles.headline: As Debt Rises, the Government Will Soon Spend More on Interest Than on the Military
articles.snippet: Tax cuts, spending increases and higher interest rates could make it harder to respond to future recessions and deal with other needs.
articles.abstract: Tax cuts, spending increases and higher interest rates could make it harder to respond to future recessions and deal with other needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government could soon pay more in interest on its debt than it spends on the military, Medicaid or children’s programs.

articles.headline: Is a New Russian Meddling Tactic Hiding in Plain Sight?
articles.snippet: USAReally might look like any other fledgling news organization. But some cybersecurity experts believe it may be part of a retooled Russian propaganda operation.
articles.abstract: USAReally might look like any other fledgling news organization. But some cybersecurity experts believe it may be part of a retooled Russian propaganda operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: To an untrained eye, USAReally might look like any other fledgling news organization vying for attention in a crowded media landscape. Its website publishes a steady stream of stories on hot-button political issues like race, immigration and income inequality. It has reader polls, a video section and a daily podcast.

articles.headline: The Continental Shock of the Kors-Versace Deal
articles.snippet: For years luxury industry wisdom had it that American brands didn’t understand European luxury. Can a surprise acquisition prove them wrong?
articles.abstract: For years luxury industry wisdom had it that American brands didn’t understand European luxury. Can a surprise acquisition prove them wrong?
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s official: America has its first global luxury group. Michael Kors’s purchase of the Italian brand Versace for $2.1 billion vaults the company — to be renamed Capri Holdings, after the Italian island — into the ranks of fashion conglomerates, a rarefied world defined by Kering and LVMH Möet Hennessy Louis Vuitton.

articles.headline: When Zuckerberg Asserted Control, Instagram’s Founders Chafed
articles.snippet: Facebook’s acquisition of the photo-sharing site was a model for making a tech deal work. But slowly losing independence was difficult to accept.
articles.abstract: Facebook’s acquisition of the photo-sharing site was a model for making a tech deal work. But slowly losing independence was difficult to accept.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a companywide meeting earlier this year, Mark Zuckerberg was asked if Instagram could have hit one billion users if it had not been bought by Facebook.

articles.headline: In a Culture of Privilege and Alcohol at Yale, Her World Converged With Kavanaugh’s
articles.snippet: Deborah Ramirez and Judge Brett Kavanaugh came to Yale from very different backgrounds. But their college circles overlapped, and during a drinking game at a dorm party, she claims, he exposed himself to her.
articles.abstract: Deborah Ramirez and Judge Brett Kavanaugh came to Yale from very different backgrounds. But their college circles overlapped, and during a drinking game at a dorm party, she claims, he exposed himself to her.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, more than 30 years after they graduated from Yale, Deborah Ramirez contacted her old friend James Roche.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul, Robin Pogrebin, Mike McIntire and Ben Protess

articles.headline: India’s Top Court Limits Sweep of Biometric ID Program
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court said the Aadhaar fingerprint ID system is legal, but restricted it to government benefits and banned companies from using it.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court said the Aadhaar fingerprint ID system is legal, but restricted it to government benefits and banned companies from using it.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In a landmark ruling on Wednesday, India’s Supreme Court placed strict limits on the government’s national biometric identity system while also finding that the sweeping program did not fundamentally violate the privacy rights of the country’s 1.3 billion residents.

articles.headline: Utilities Helped Puerto Rico Fix Its Power Grid. Now They Face Hefty Tax Bills.
articles.snippet: Electric companies across the mainland have received tax bills from Puerto Rican cities demanding millions of dollars in payments.
articles.abstract: Electric companies across the mainland have received tax bills from Puerto Rican cities demanding millions of dollars in payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: When nearly the entire power grid of Puerto Rico was knocked out by a pair of ferocious hurricanes last year, utility companies from across the United States sent crews and equipment to help.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Alejandra Rosa

articles.headline: A ‘Particularly Bright’ Moment Brings Another Fed Rate Increase
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the third time this year and signaled it was on track to raise them again in December.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the third time this year and signaled it was on track to raise them again in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s chairman, Jerome H. Powell, said on Wednesday that the American economy was experiencing “a particularly bright moment” as the Fed announced a widely expected increase in its benchmark interest rate and signaled that it planned to continue raising rates.

articles.headline: Nafta’s Fate Hinges on a Four-Letter Word: Milk
articles.snippet: Canada’s dairy protections have become a key sticking point in Nafta and a potential roadblock to a trilateral deal with the United States and Mexico.
articles.abstract: Canada’s dairy protections have become a key sticking point in Nafta and a potential roadblock to a trilateral deal with the United States and Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — For the seasonal salad at the popular Oz Kafe here, the shavings of Gouda cheese are a salty and delicious culinary accompaniment. To the United States, they are an element of an increasingly bitter trade dispute over dairy products, one that threatens to undermine its decades-long agreement with Canada.

articles.headline: How Apple Thrived in a Season of Tech Scandals
articles.snippet: Everyone is worried about the power of big technology companies. Apple alone has managed to turn the fears into an argument for its own business model.
articles.abstract: Everyone is worried about the power of big technology companies. Apple alone has managed to turn the fears into an argument for its own business model.
articles.lead_paragraph: The business world has long been plagued by Apple catastrophists — investors, analysts, rival executives and journalists who look at the world’s most valuable company and proclaim it to be imminently doomed.

articles.headline: Cheaper Battery Is Unveiled as a Step to a Carbon-Free Grid
articles.snippet: The entrepreneur Patrick Soon-Shiong says his company’s tests of zinc-based storage for solar and wind energy show the potential for large-scale use.
articles.abstract: The entrepreneur Patrick Soon-Shiong says his company’s tests of zinc-based storage for solar and wind energy show the potential for large-scale use.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lithium-ion batteries have become essential for powering electric cars and storing energy generated by solar panels and wind turbines. But their drawbacks are also by now familiar: They use scarce minerals, are vulnerable to fires and explosions, and are pricey.

articles.headline: Trump Accuses China of Interfering in Midterm Elections
articles.snippet: The president offered no evidence of Chinese meddling in the November vote, but he has previously accused China of aiming tariffs at American states that support him.
articles.abstract: The president offered no evidence of Chinese meddling in the November vote, but he has previously accused China of aiming tariffs at American states that support him.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump on Wednesday accused a foreign power of meddling in an American election: not Russia, but China.

articles.headline: Before Kavanaugh Hearing, New Accusations and Doubts Emerge
articles.snippet: A new accuser and fresh evidence confronted the Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh before a make-or-break hearing with a woman who says he assaulted her.
articles.abstract: A new accuser and fresh evidence confronted the Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh before a make-or-break hearing with a woman who says he assaulted her.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated Sept. 27, 2018: Christine Blasey Ford testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday about her allegations against Judge Kavanaugh. Follow our live coverage.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Michael D. Shear
